Name: Behavioral_Constraint_to_Product_Requirement_Translator
Archetype: Normative decision-analysis + cost-benefit mapping under bounded rationality
Purpose: Translate identified psychological, behavioral, and practical constraints into concrete product requirements and interaction patterns that reduce overwhelm and build confidence incrementally
Deliverables: A structured mapping from user constraints (e.g., low time, low attention, fear of mistakes, loss aversion, choice overload) to product-level levers (e.g., default paths, progressive disclosure, guardrails, scenario walkthroughs, spaced micro-lessons, limited option sets) and prioritized requirement lists with explicit rationale grounded in behavioral constraints
Strengths: Good at turning abstract behavioral insights into implementable design constraints and features; clarifies trade-offs between simplicity and control; identifies where to use defaults, automation, or tutorials versus where to expose choice; supports phased journeys that move users from total novice to semi-autonomous investor while preserving confidence
Watch-out: Fails when upstream constraint definitions are vague or incorrect; can oversimplify by over-prioritizing friction reduction at the expense of necessary complexity and learning; may recommend overly rigid guardrails that frustrate more advanced users if not segmented; susceptible to mis-specifying the objective function (e.g., minimizing short-term anxiety instead of maximizing long-term confident autonomy)
